title: Family Ties
plot_outline: Chronicles liberal ex-hippies Steven and Elyse Keaton, their conservative son Alex, daughters Mallory and Jennifer, and later, youngest child Andrew.
keywords: [u'liberal', u'conservative', u'young-republican', u'columbus-ohio', u'overalls', u'generation-gap', u'culture-clash', u'1980s', u'laugh-track', u'politics', u'mother-son-relationship', u'mother-daughter-relationship', u'husband-wife-relationship', u'father-son-relationship', u'father-daughter-relationship', u'family-relationships', u'greed', u'advice', u'sitcom', u'brother-sister-relationship', u'sister-sister-relationship', u'marriage', u'ex-hippie']
taglines: [u"It looks like we don't have any Taglines for this title yet."]
trivia: [u"The cast wanted to end the show with the entire Keaton family dying in a plane crash. They absolutely didn't want to do a reunion show in the future.", u"According to Michael J. Fox's last Spin City (1996) episode, Alex P. Keaton became a Junior Congressman from Ohio.", u'In one of his autobiographies, Michael J. Fox said that for at least ten years after his marriage to Tracy Pollan, the two couldn\'t get on a dance floor anywhere in the country without someone starting to play the 1981 song "At This Moment" by Billy Vera and The Beaters because of its strong association with the romance storyline between Fox\'s and Pollan\'s characters Alex and Ellen.', u"Tom Hanks played Elise Keaton's brother Ned.", u"Michael J. Fox added the P. in Alex P. Keaton as an ad-lib in his audition, the writers loved it and kept it. Michael J. Fox almost didn't get the role of Alex, due to the fact that NBC executive Brandon Tartikoff didn't find it believable that Meredith Baxter and Michael Gross would have a son that was so short.", u'Alex was born in Africa when Elyse and Steven were serving in the Peace Corps.', u"Tracy Pollan, who played Alex Keaton's girlfriend Ellen, later married Michael J. Fox in real-life.", u"Alex and Ellen's love theme was At This Moment by Billy Vera and The Beaters. The song was originally recorded and released in 1981, and went largely unnoticed. After being featured on the series, the single was re-released in the Fall of 1986, and reached Number One on the Billboard Top 100 Pop Chart in early 1987.", u'The show was modelled after Producer Gary David Goldberg and wife Diane\'s real-life experiences as former "hippies" transforming into suburban family life.', u'When Meredith Baxter became pregnant during the hiatus between the second and third seasons, her pregnancy was written into the show. However, she still was written out of several episodes after giving birth to twins in real-life.', u"Michael J. Fox's first audition was deemed terrible by Gary Goldberg, because Fox came off too smart-aleck. Casting Director Judith Wiener really liked Fox and begged Goldberg to see him a second time. Fox took a different approach, the audition went great, and Fox was offered the part.", u"Michael Gross once stated in an interview that he didn't feel that Steven Keaton had much dimension or depth until the character of Nick was added. He cited this addition as a major reason for staying on the show.", u'The black Labrador that appeared after the closing credits with the voice-over, "Sit Ubu, sit", was Gary David Goldberg\'s dog, Ubu.', u'Mallory\'s boyfriend Nick was only intended to be a "one shot" character. Scott Valentine made a strong impression on the show\'s audience and producers, resulting in Nick becoming a recurring character on the series. Nick proved to be so popular, that the producers tried to spin him off into his own series, though the pilot never sold.', u"One year before playing Michael J. Fox's father in Back to the Future (1985), Crispin Glover played Alex P. Keaton's friend in the episode Family Ties: Birthday Boy (1984). Fox and Glover appeared in High School U.S.A. (1983) as well.", u'Gary David Goldberg named the family Keaton after Diane Keaton.', u"President Ronald Reagan's declaration of this being his favorite television show lead to rumors of talks for him to make a cameo, or perhaps guest starring role, on the series.", u"Ed O'Neill was considered for the role of Steven Keaton.", u"An episode set to air shortly before the 1988 Presidential election was to have featured a scene showing Alex's bedroom full of George Bush campaign posters and related items. The scene was dropped, as NBC felt it could be viewed as overtly political and potentially violated Equal Time laws. Instead, a scene was shown after the election, where Alex hung up and admired a poster of Bush in the living room to celebrate his victory.", u'The show was a long-time staple of NBC\'s "Must See TV" Thursday night line-up. After season five, the show moved from Thursday night following The Cosby Show (1984) to Sunday night. The show dropped from second place in the ratings to number seventeen due to the move. The ratings declined even further in season seven, and the show was cancelled.', u'On some days during the shoot of the first season, Fox would often hitchhike from Brentwood to Hollywood, because he had no car.', u"The producers originally wanted Matthew Broderick to play Alex P. Keaton, but the actor had to decline the role when his father became terminally ill. Coincidentally, Broderick's father James Broderick played Meredith Baxter's father on the drama Family (1976).", u'The political themes were heavily emphasized in early seasons of the series. However, as the show progressed and the focus moved on Alex and the children, the political themes were downplayed or used in a more light hearted manner in later seasons.', u"Michael J. Fox was approached during the second season about starring in Back to the Future (1985). But executive producer Gary David Goldberg would not allow Fox the time off to make the film. Because of delays in the film, Fox was approached again during the third season. This time, Goldberg and the film's producers worked out a schedule that would allow Fox to work on both projects simultaneously. Mondays to Thursdays, Fox would rehearse for the series during the day, and work on the film all night. On Friday nights, the series would tape their episodes. As soon taping finished, he would go to the film's set and work all weekend.", u'U.S. President Ronald Reagan declared this his favorite television show during the 1980s.', u"The series was intended to be a starring vehicle for Meredith Baxter and Michael Gross. As a result, the show's initial focus was more on the parents, with the kids more as background characters. The kids, Alex in particular, quickly came to gain a more equal, and eventually greater focus, as Michael J. Fox established himself as the series break-out star.", u'Michael Gross and Meredith Baxter share the same birthday: June 21, 1947. Gross was born in Chicago, Illinois, and Baxter was born in Los Angeles, California.', u"Meredith Baxter at times was rumored to have wanted to leave the series. This was said to be due over tensions between her and Michael J. Fox, as Fox had largely usurped the show's intended focus away from Baxter and Michael Gross. Baxter and Fox have indicated that there was nothing to the reports over any feuds or tension between them.", u"Throughout the series' run, exterior establishment shots of the Keaton home were never used in any of the episodes, which is very unusual for a family sitcom. The vast majority of all scenes were played out in the kitchen.", u"Alex's (Michael J. Fox's) hero is Richard Nixon. Skippy (Marc Price) (the perpetual Alex wanna-be) admired Gerald Ford.", u'Alex attended Leland University, a play on Stanford University (sometimes referred to as the conservative Harvard or Harvard of the west coast), which was named for Leland Stanford.', u'The name "Mallory" translates to (depending on who you ask) as either "failure, unlucky, or ill-omened" which is fitting with the character.', u"All of the stars of Stand by Me (1986) appeared on this show as friends or classmates of Jennifer Keaton, except Jerry O'Connell. River Phoenix, Will Wheaton, and Corey Feldman all made cameos on the program in Jennifer-centric episodes.", u'Skippy was adopted as a baby.', u'Columbus, Ohio was selected as the setting of the series as that section of the country is viewed as being "middle America".', u'According to the memoir "Lucky Man", shortly before Fox won the role of Alex P. Keaton, Fox\'s father had written him a letter and encouraged him to "pull the curtain" on his acting career in Los Angeles given his recent struggles. A few weeks later, he was taking a bus to work everyday to shoot the show.', u'Meredith Baxter and Michael Gross, each born on June 21, 1947, are only fourteen years older than Michael J. Fox, born June 9, 1961.', u'This show was set in Columbus, Ohio.', u'At least two different pilots for a potential spin off series featuring Nick (Scott Valentine) were produced and aired, though neither was picked up by NBC.', u'The character "Steven Keaton" was ranked #12 in TV Guide\'s list of the "50 Greatest TV Dads of All Time" (June 20, 2004 issue).', u"Featured a young Courteney Cox as Alex's girlfriend in a few episodes .", u'Michael Gross made a crossover appearance as Steven Keaton on the short lived NBC Sitcom Day by Day (1988), which like Family Ties was created and produced by Gary David Goldberg.', u'Jennifer was born on Election Day 1972.', u'In March 2008, Gary David Goldberg wrote an essay for The New York Times speculating about what Alex Keaton\'s political beliefs would be now. Goldberg said that Keaton, as a "true Conservative Republican", would probably no longer feel comfortable in the Republican Party of the late 2000s, "a party whose legacy will include Terri Schiavo and Hurricane Katrina, (and) waging war against science." Goldberg said that Keaton would have supported McCain in 2000, but no obvious candidate in the 2008 race. He also said that he and Michael J. Fox have different ideas about Keaton\'s current career; Goldberg thinks Keaton is a pro bono lawyer for the Children\'s Defense Fund, while Fox believes Keaton is finishing a prison sentence.', u'The name of the public television station, for which Stephen worked, was WKS, a fictional station.', u'In her memoir "Untied: A Memoir of Family, Fame and Floundering", Meredith Baxter talks about tension on the set of this show. She talks about how she and Michael Gross were annoyed that Michael J. Fox was getting all the attention, and their characters were basically being ignored. At one point, in a sign of protest, they walked on the set with one leg bonded together (like they were running a three-legged race). They made a speech to everyone about how they were tied together because their characters were bland and interchangeable, one boring "uni-parent" creature. Series Executive Producer Gary David Goldberg ignored their protests.', u'The Goonies (1985) stars Martha Plimpton, Jeff Cohen, and Corey Feldman all made appearances on this show.', u"Elyse's maiden name was Donelly.", u'Steven Keaton was from Buffalo, New York.', u"In the show, Meredith Baxter and Michael Gross play extreme liberal activists who show annoyance towards their son Alex's love of President Richard Nixon. However, in All the President's Men (1976), Baxter portrayed Debbie Sloan, the wife of Richard Nixon White House staffer and Watergate conspirator Hugh Sloan.", u'Mallory (Justine Bateman) and Skippy (Marc Price) attended Grant Junior College, a fictional school.', u'Tina Yothers released a single when she was on this show, called "Baby I\'m Back In Love Again". It\'s the song her band sings in the "Band on the Run" episode. Unfortunately, it never cracked the top 40.', u'Throughout the series, no one other than the six Keatons was ever a series regular featured in the opening credits.', u'This show benefitted from following The Cosby Show (1984) every Thursday night on NBC. However, prior to the 1987-1988 season, Bill Cosby requested that another show focusing on African-Americans follow his, due to the low number of them on television at the time. The result was A Different World (1987), a show he helped create and produce, that focused on an African-American college. This show was moved to Sunday night, where it took a big dip in the ratings. The show was cancelled in 1989 as the ratings continued to decline.', u'Christina Applegate made an appearance as a member of Jennifer\'s band "Permanent Wave".', u"Scott Valentine wore a long shaggy wig for the role of Mallory's boyfriend Nick Moore. Valentine's real hair can be seen in the episode Mr. Right from season four when Nick gives himself a clean cut makeover to impress Mallory's parents.", u'In at least two episodes of season six, Jennifer appears as being much younger, and the toddler Andy is noticeably absent. These episodes were recycled from unused episodes of earlier seasons, and used as "fillers" in the production run for the sixth season.', u'Alex, Mallory, and Skippy attended Harding High School. Jennifer went to Randolph elementary. Although there are two "Harding" high schools in Ohio, both named after the 29th President of the United States Warren G. Harding, there is no school by that name in the area in and around Columbus, Ohio. Which doesn\'t matter, since it\'s a fictional show.', u"Some critics and other media observers have come to see this show as a reverse parallel to All in the Family (1971). Both shows largely centered around political or philosophical generation gaps, with this show reversing All In The Family's dynamic of conservative parents and liberal kids. Gary David Goldberg has said that hadn't been his intention, calling the reverse similarities a happy accident.", u'Meredith Baxter and Michael Gross, each born on June 21, 1947, are only eleven years older than Scott Valentine, born on June 3, 1958.', u'Tina Yothers is half-Mexican.', u'Stars of A League of Their Own (1992), Tom Hanks and Geena Davis, guest-starred on this show, but in separate episodes.', u'Corey Feldman makes an appearance in "The Disciple". Oddly enough, even though Corey was a big star at this point, this is only a very small cameo. He only has a couple of lines, and does not interact at all with any of the principals.', u'It is never revealed what the "P" in Alex P. Keaton stands for.', u"Daphne Zuniga, who played Alex Keaton's date Rachel Miller in season one, later starred opposite Eric Stoltz in The Fly II (1989). Michael J. Fox replaced Eric Stoltz as Marty McFly in Back to the Future (1985).", u'Jennifer is said to have been born on Election Day in 1972. In real-life, Tina Yothers was born on May 5, 1973, making the actress six months younger than her character, an abnormality for sitcoms, which almost always cast performers who are a few years older than their pre-teen or teen-aged characters. By comparison, Bateman was two and a half years older than Mallory, and Fox was four years older than Alex.', u"Was Ronald Reagan's favorite show. Certainly that it made it popular and cool for awhile to be a business major, GQ clothed, neo-con Republican; teased by your family, but still the coolest, most impressive, and well-dressed person in the house.", u'Meredith Baxter Birney went from being the kid on one show (Family (1976)) to the Mom on a show right afterwards (Family Ties (1982)).', u"Spawned many clones and ripoffs, like ABC's Growing Pains (1985).", u'Crispin Glover made his only appearance, on this show, in the episode "Birthday Boy". Glover\'s guest starring role as Alex\'s friend Doug was not a recurring or semi regular role as some falsely believe.']
release_dates: [u'USA::22 September 1982', u'West Germany::26 May 1984', u'UK::6 July 1985', u'Netherlands::14 June 1986', u'France::20 September 1987', u'Denmark::14 July 1989', u'Sweden::November 1990']

title: Bright Lights, Big City
plot_outline: A disillusioned young writer living in New York City turns to drugs and drinking to block out the memories of his dead mother and estranged wife.
keywords: [u'writer', u'new-york-city', u'nightclub', u'magazine', u'cocaine', u'yuppie', u'estranged-wife', u'dead-mother', u'screenplay-adapted-by-author', u'world-trade-center', u'sunglasses', u'bald-woman', u'world-trade-center-manhattan-new-york-city', u'manhattan-new-york-city', u'urban-setting', u'self-destructiveness', u'drunkenness', u'cousin-cousin-relationship', u'brother-sister-relationship', u'tabloid', u'mannequin', u'magazine-editor', u'subway', u'self-discovery', u'nosebleed', u'nightlife', u'newspaper', u'mother-son-relationship', u'model', u'magazine-publisher', u'lesbian-kiss', u'journalist', u'innocence-lost', u'flashback', u'fetus', u'ferret', u'fashion-show', u'editor', u'drug-addiction', u'drug-abuse', u'dream', u'bread', u'big-city', u'alcoholism', u'new-wave', u'club', u'bar', u'night-life', u'based-on-novel']
taglines: [u'All that glitters is not gold.', u"It's 6.00am. Do you know where you are?", u"He's a long way from Kansas."]
trivia: [u'In a 2011 interview with "The A. V. Club," David Hyde Pierce said that it cost him more to join the Screen Actors Guild (so that he could appear in this movie) than he was paid for his role, so he had to borrow the dues money from his agent. His character\'s name was "Bartender at Fashion Show",and his one line was, "Sorry, the bar is closed."', u"Even though they had worked together on Family Ties (1982), Michael J. Fox and Tracy Pollan didn't begin dating until they worked together on this film.", u'Debut theatrical feature film of actor David Hyde Pierce.', u'Second and final of two late 1980s movies where Michael J. Fox played a yuppie in New York City. The first being,', u"Tom Cruise turned down the part of Jamie, as he didn't like the idea of scenes involving him taking drugs.", u"Before hiring Michael J. Fox, casting was about to cast a man working at Tiffany's in New York City named Chris Salales. They might have given him the starring role, despite his lack of any prior experience.", u'The substance used to depict cocaine, was really a powdered milk prop known as "milk sugar".', u'The book "Bright Lights, Big City" is one of the few well-known novels in the English language written in second person ("you") form, and the film\'s narration is a result of this adaptation. Much of the narration is lifted directly or adapted from the novel; for example, the movie\'s first line, "You are not the kind of guy who would be at a place like this at this time of the morning..." is also the first line of the book.', u'Michael J. Fox suggested Kiefer Sutherland for the role of Tad Allagash.', u"Michael J. Fox's casting increased the budget to fifteen million dollars.", u"Filming on-location in New York City, was often disrupted by Michael J. Fox's female fans.", u'Judd Nelson, Emilio Estevez, and Rob Lowe were considered for the role of Allagash.', u'The name of Michael J. Fox\'s character, Jamie Conway, is almost an anagram of author Jay McInerney\'s name. In the novel, the main character\'s full name is never given, he is referred to as "Coach" by Tad, and in the second person ("you") in the narration.', u"In 1985, Jerry Weintraub became the chief executive of United Artists, and brought this property with him. Since that meant he couldn't or wouldn't be able to produce it, he looked around for another producer. Sydney Pollack and Mark Rosenberg agreed to do it, but wanted a re-write of the script. They hired Julie Hickson to write a script. Tom Cruise and Joel Schumacher grew tired of waiting for a workable script, but before they could be replaced, Weintraub left United Artists. The project became entangled in a complicated settlement with the studio, months being lost, before it finally stayed at United Artists.", u"According to Jay McInerney, Tom Cole wrote all the drugs out of the script. Cole claims that he did so on instructions from Sydney Pollack, who was worried that the film would hurt Michael J. Fox's wholesome image.", u"Ulu Grosbard and Bruce Beresford were considered to direct before James Bridges was chosen. Bridges received a call on a Friday that the film was in trouble, read the novel that night, and flew to New York City on Sunday. He saw Joyce Chopra's footage and agreed to direct, if he could start from scratch and hire Gordon Willis as his Cinematographer.", u'In seven days, James Bridges wrote a new draft and got rid of six cast members, casting instead Jason Robards, Jr. John Houseman, Swoosie Kurtz, Frances Sternhagen, and Tracy Pollan, while keeping Kiefer Sutherland and Dianne Wiest. Those cast members took the part based on a reading of the novel, since there was no script at the time.', u"Penultimate credited film of John Houseman. Houseman's final credited role was in Woody Allen's Another Woman (1988).", u'"Gotham", the fictitious New York magazine for which Jamie Conway works as a fact-checker, is clearly an unflattering caricature of "The New Yorker", where Author and Screenwriter Jay McInerney had also worked as a fact-checker.', u'Star Billing: Michael J. Fox (first), Kiefer Sutherland (second), Phoebe Cates (third), Swoosie Kurtz (fourth), and Frances Sternhagen (fifth).', u'The movie was filmed during April, May, and June 1987.', u"The film was released four years after Author and Screenwriter Jay McInerney published the book. The book also inspired a rock musical of the same name, which premiered in 1999 at the New York Theatre Workshop, where Rent had premiered several years earlier. The musical wasn't as successful as its predecessor, but the score was later released as a studio album.", u'Ulu Grosbard and Bruce Beresford were considered to take over the directing reigns from Joyce Chopra. In the end, the job went to James Bridges.', u'Two members of the Robards family appear in this movie, Jason Robards, Jr. and Sam Robards, who are father and son respectively.', u'The nickname for cocaine in the novel and the screenplay is "Bolivian Marching Powder".', u'Gordon Willis replaced Jim Glennon as Director of Photography.', u"Final film directed by James Bridges. The picture was Bridges' first film in about three years, the last having been Perfect (1985).", u'The film cast includes three Oscar winners: Dianne Wiest, Jason Robards, Jr., John Houseman; and one Oscar nominee: William Hickey.', u'Robert Lawrence, a Vice President at Columbia Pictures, championed the novel against resistance from older executives. He felt that the book spoke to his generation and described it as "The Graduate (1967), with a little bit of The Lost Weekend (1945)".', u'Jay McInerney wrote a draft of the script. It was to have been directed by Joel Schumacher, produced by Jerry Weintraub, and starred Tom Cruise. McInerney, Cruise, and Schumacher had been involved enough to have scouted locations in New York City, and checked out the atmosphere of the club scenes described in the novel, before they dropped out following production delays.', u"Michael J. Fox's schedule with Family Ties (1982) left Joyce Chopra only ten weeks to finish the film.", u'It was rumored that Joyce Chopra was indecisive, relying too much on consulting with James Glennon and Tom Cole, wasting time over a single shot.', u'The filmmakers shot two different endings, one where Jamie decides to start his life all over, and an alternate one, to please the studio, where he has finished writing a novel to be called "Bright Lights, Big City" with a new girlfriend, who is proud of what he has written.', u"Studio executives did not like what Joyce Chopra was shooting and, a week into filming, the studio's chairman and its president of production flew from Los Angeles to New York City to check on the film. Neither executive had read the script, and they were unaware of how different it was from the novel.", u'Joyce Chopra worked on the film for only a month, which Michael J. Fox described as "a rehearsal period, though it wasn\'t meant to be."', u"A possible director's strike forced the production to shoot in seven weeks and use Jay McInerney's first draft, which James Bridges liked the best. Bridges worked on the script on weekends with McInerney, who was enlisted to help with revisions. The two agreed to share screenwriting credit, but the Writers Guild of America decided to credit McInerney alone.", u'Jason Robards, Jr. replaced John McMartin on this troubled shoot.', u'(Jay McInerney on director James Bridges) "I think we\'re probably lucky that (Jim) was not a thirty-two year old director. I often feared that someone was going to try to make a music video out of my book."', u'Paramount initially showed interest in the novel, but after flying McInerney to Hollywood, a shake-up in management caused the project to be dropped. Jerry Weintraub and Columbia Pictures commissioned three drafts of a screenplay from McInerney, but the author heard nothing back from him. Ultimately, three years later Bridges entered the picture.', u'Reportedly, United Artists acquired the film rights to the book in 1986.', u'Apparently, Michael J. Fox wanted to change his image, born from sitcom and light movie fare, which is why he did this picture.', u'One of numerous 1980s motion pictures made about "yuppies".', u'Second and final of two theatrical film collaborations by veteran Hollywood actor John Houseman and Director James Bridges. The first had been The Paper Chase (1973), for which Houseman had won the Best Actor in a Supporting Role Academy Award.', u'Some felt that Michael J. Fox was too young for the lead role, and that Phoebe Cates was unconvincing as a fashion model.', u'Jason Robards: Uncredited, as drunken writer Mr. Hardy.', u'Dianne Wiest: As the mother of Michael J. Fox. Her character is never known by any personal name, and is billed in the credits only as "Mother".', u'David Hyde Pierce: As a bartender at a fashion show.', u'William Hickey: As Ferret Man.', u'John Houseman: As Mr. Vogel.']

title: The Secret of My Succe$s

taglines: [u"There's no such thing as an overnight success.  Brantley Foster took two weeks."]
trivia: [u"The original script was about a young man working for his uncle and falling in love with his uncle's prostitute. Universal executive Frank Price called in Jim Cash and Jack Epps, Jr. to re-write the script in eight weeks. They changed Christy Willis from a prostitute to a mistress, and added the complication with Aunt Vera.", u'When Brantley, a non-smoker, puts his feet up on the desk, he reveals dozens of burn marks. At the time, Michael J. Fox was a heavy smoker. The burn marks are the result of Fox extinguishing cigarettes with his shoe.', u"Kristy McNichol was Herbert Ross' original choice for lead actress. She was fired two weeks before filming, because of fears she might be difficult to work with, due to her bipolar disorder.", u"Michael J. Fox and Helen Slater's kissing scenes required a lot of height adjustments, because Fox is much shorter than Slater.", u'A sequel was proposed, but never made.', u'Unused music by John Williams.', u'The picture has often been likened by critics and audiences to the earlier movie How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying (1967).', u"David Watkin was the film's original cinematographer. According to his autobiography, the reasons for being dismissed were, and still are, unknown.", u'This film was inspired by the early Hollywood experiences of Steven Spielberg, who snuck onto the Universal Studios lot at a young age and began using an empty office as his own production office. The character of Brantley Foster does the same thing in this movie.', u'The movie was filmed during June, July, and August 1986.', u'First of two late 1980s movies where Michael J. Fox played a yuppie in New York City. The second film was Manhattanin valot (1988).', u'One of numerous 1980s motion pictures made about "yuppies".', u"Cinematographer Carlo Di Palma visually designed the movie's shot to be a pictorial presentation of the main characters' dreams and ambitions.", u'Filming commenced on August 1, 1986, and Michael J. Fox began filming the fifth season of Family Ties (1982) the next day.', u'Michael J. Fox filmed this film and Light of Day (1987) during the same hiatus in between the fourth and fifth seasons of Family Ties (1982)', u'This movie was filmed at around thirty-five locations in New York City.', u'Brantley Foster and Katrina Leskanich of Katrina & The Waves, who sing "Walking On Sunshine", are from Kansas.', u'The spelling of this movie\'s title The Secret of My Succe$s (1987) had the phrase stylized by forming a \'$\' symbol out of the "Success" word\'s second letter \'S\' character.', u"The book that can be seen on Vera's bed when Howard sneaks out of the bedroom is Ch\xe9ri and The Last of Ch\xe9ri written by Colette.", u'According to the American Film Institute: "Rastar Production had filed a lawsuit against distributor Universal Studios concerning the dispersal of profits after the breakeven point. No information about the outcome of the lawsuit has been found."', u'Quoted from the American Film Institute: "A three hundred-acre estate on the Hudson River near Mount Kisco, New York, one hour from midtown Manhattan, was used for the Prescott estate sequences."', u"The production notes on the DVD state that this movie was Herbert Ross' twentieth feature film.", u'One of two cinema movies first released in the year of 1987 that were directed by director Herbert Ross. The films are Dancers (1987) and this movie.', u'Chris Marney, the mail room boss, bears a striking resemblance to Robert Morse, who played a Brantley Whitfield like part in "How to Succeed in Business... without really trying". In that film, the first rule of success was " Get out of the mail room as soon as possible!"', u"When Howard's secretary is talking to him about seeing Brantley, the execs that just came out of his office are waiting for the elevator. One of them says it can't be good for Howard's heart to yell then another says he doesn't have a heart. All of this is said in front of Howard's lackey, Art, who is known for being a tattletale.", u'Cindy Crawford: In the opening credits, the third of four models who turns her head in rapid succession.', u'Tatjana Patitz: In the opening credits, the fourth of four models who turns her head in rapid succession.', u"In the final scene, Christy (Helen Slater) is seen admiring a ring on the ring finger of her left hand. It's likely that she and Brantley (Michael J. Fox) have become engaged by this stage of the movie."]
release_dates: [u'USA::7 April 1987 (Los Angeles, California)\n (premiere)', u'USA::10 April 1987', u'Argentina::21 May 1987', u'Japan::20 June 1987', u'Australia::25 June 1987', u'UK::26 June 1987', u'Ireland::26 June 1987', u'Brazil::22 July 1987', u'France::22 July 1987', u'Italy::1 August 1987 (Rome premiere)', u'Netherlands::6 August 1987', u'Portugal::14 August 1987', u'Sweden::14 August 1987', u'Philippines::September 1987', u'Denmark::4 September 1987', u'Finland::4 September 1987', u'West Germany::10 September 1987', u'Italy::5 October 1987', u'Spain::14 October 1987 (Madrid)\n (premiere)', u'Spain::23 October 1987', u'Taiwan::24 October 1987', u'South Korea::3 March 1990']

title: Light of Day
plot_outline: The siblings Patty and Joe Rasnick live in an industrial suburb in Cleveland, Ohio. While Patty is focused on their rock band...
keywords: [u'rock-band', u'family-relationships', u'brother-sister-relationship', u"rock-'n'-roll", u'musician', u'rock-music', u'medical', u'single-mother', u'working-class', u'cancer', u'uncle', u'cleveland-ohio', u'mother-son-relationship', u'hospital', u'fictional-band', u'independent-film']
taglines: [u'"La rage au ventre, la musique dans la peau." (Rage in the belly, music in the skin) - France DVD case', u'"I got a little lost along the way, but I\'m just around the corner to the light of day." - Bruce Springsteen', u'When your family is closing you in, music may be the only way out.']
trivia: [u'This is one of the very few projects that Michael J. Fox has smoked in front of the camera. Although a chain smoker, he avoided being photographed with a cigarette, out of fear that it would encourage smoking.', u'This film was actually offered to Bruce Springsteen as an acting project (for what became the Michael J. Fox role) when he was thinking about going into film acting. He ultimately passed on this project (and dismissed the idea of going into films altogether).', u'The original title of the script was "Born in the U.S.A." Paul Schrader asked Bruce Springsteen to write a title song for the movie. After Springsteen wrote it, he liked the song so much, he used for his multi-platinum album of the same name instead. As a replacement, Springsteen later wrote the song "Light of Day". That is why Springsteen thanks Schrader in the liner notes of the album.', u'The final scene, where the Barbusters perform in front of an adoring crowd, was shot twice. Bits of the first version can be seen in the music video for the song "Light of Day" (where Joan Jett\'s hair is in a noticeably different, fluffier style). Rolling Stone magazine reported that Jett was not happy with the first version, and asked that it be re-shot. Director Paul Schrader said, "I was about to leave the set and wait out the storm in my trailer, but I listened to her arguments, and decided she was right."', u'A young Trent Reznor appears, with other members of (his band at the time) Exotic Birds in the film as a member of the fictional band, The Problems.', u'Paul Schrader expressed dissatisfaction with this film, particularly its plain visual style: "I had progressed from being a person with a literary vision to a person with a visual vision, and in that film, I tried to, suppress my new literacy" and the casting of Joan Jett: "it\'s a good performance, but that piece of casting just did not work."']

title: Teen Wolf
plot_outline: An ordinary high school student discovers that his family has an unusual pedigree when he finds himself turning into a werewolf.
keywords: [u'school', u'basketball', u'high-school', u'basketball-team', u'high-school-student', u'best-friend', u'whistle', u'dog-whistle', u'werewolf', u'coach', u'party', u'full-moon', u'teen-movie', u'teen-comedy', u'cult-film', u'man-in-towel', u'seductive-woman', u'woman-in-underwear', u'breakdance', u'headmaster', u'mistaken-for-being-gay', u'male-dressed-as-female', u'party-game', u'draw', u'jelly', u'barefoot-on-street', u'barefoot-male', u'taking-off-shoes', u'underage-drinking', u'masturbation-reference', u'rehearsal', u'chest-hair', u'male-in-shower', u'taking-a-shower', u'bare-chested-male', u'locker-room', u'group-shower', u'basketball-coach', u'body-hair', u'rivalry', u'teenager', u'teenage-protagonist', u'vice-principal', u'sunglasses', u'mascot', u't-shirt', u'dressing-room', u'adult-actress-playing-teenage-girl', u'adult-actor-playing-teenage-boy', u'bra-removing', u'bra-and-panties', u'towel', u'lycanthrope', u'1980s', u'basketball-movie', u'supernatural-power', u'shaving', u'howling', u'teenage-girl', u'boyfriend-girlfriend-relationship', u'love', u'puberty', u'father-son-relationship', u'spontaneous-choreography', u'sports-team', u'teenage-boy', u'role-reversal', u'drug-abuse', u'teen-angst', u'shape-shifter', u'parody', u'coming-of-age', u'gay-slur', u'marijuana', u'beer', u'dance', u'van', u'surfing', u'liquor-store', u'hardware-store', u'school-play', u'cannabis', u'bowling', u'independent-film']
taglines: [u'MICHAEL J. FOX is back from the future in a NEW COMEDY...', u'He always wanted to be special... but he never expected this!']
trivia: [u"Scott Howard's (Michael J. Fox's) house was located on the same block as 1955 George McFly's and 1955 Lorraine Baines' houses from Back to the Future (1985).", u'Michael J. Fox disliked this film so much, that he refused to return for the sequel. In an interview at the time, while Back to the Future (1985) was in production, he lamented, "Steven Spielberg\'s down the street making great movies and I\'m playing a werewolf."', u'Since this movie was released after Back to the Future (1985) in Brazil, "Teen Wolf" received the title "Garoto do Futuro" ("Boy from the Future") there, even though the plot has nothing to do with time travel whatsoever.', u"Tampa Bay Buccaneers defensive end Greg White officially changed his name to Stylez G. White on December 15, 2008. The inspiration for the name change came from Jerry Levine's character, Stiles, in this movie.", u'If the "teen" actors seem too old to be high school students, it\'s no wonder. Scott is played by Michael J. Fox: age 23. Stiles is played by Jerry Levine: age 27. Chubby is played by Mark Holton: age 26. Mick is played by Mark Arnold: age 27.', u'According to Rod Daniel, when test audiences first saw Scott\'s dad as a werewolf, "they went insane." He said the laughter was so loud "it obliterated the next minute of the film."', u'The jersey worn by Michael J. Fox was sold to Dina Collection (Beverly Hills pawn shop) for thirty thousand dollars.', u"Michael J. Fox's fame rose steadily while filming, due to the increasing success of Family Ties (1982). By the end of production, Fox needed more security than he did at the beginning.", u'Lisa "Boof" Marconi was based on one of the writer\'s high school girlfriends. That was really her name.', u'The entire production took only twenty-one days.', u'According to Rod Daniel, "Somewhere in a vault is about an hour of the most embarrassing sports footage ever taken."', u'Co-screenwriters Jeph Loeb and Matthew Weisman interviewed several directors for the movie. They asked the directors what they thought the movie was about. Most said it was about a werewolf. Rod Daniel was the only one who said it was about a father and son. He got the job.', u'"Teen Wolf", whose Italian title is "Voglia di Vincere" ("Desire to win"), was released in Italy shortly after Back to the Future (1985). Due to this, the main character\'s name Scott was changed to "Marty", the same name as Michael J. Fox\'s character in the Robert Zemeckis\' film.', u'Rod Daniel went to Nebraska, where the movie is set, to interview teens about partying. The interviews inspired many of the scenes.', u'When Susan Ursitti slapped Michael J. Fox, she did it too hard at first. Rod Daniel had to explain what a softer "stage slap" was.', u'Rod Daniel voiced all the growls in the movie. He joked, "And I didn\'t get a nickel."', u'The werewolf make-up took nearly four hours to apply, but it only took James Hampton thirty seconds to rip it off. It made him feel claustrophobic.', u"James Hampton, who played Scott Howard's father Harold, said at a recent Teen Wolf Convention that he was originally cast as Coach Finstock, played by Jay Tarses.", u"The film was delayed from it's original Spring 1985 release date because of Back to the Future (1985), which would go on to become the blockbuster at Universal, as Paramount and the production company, Atlantic Releasing Corporation wanted to capitalize on Michael J. Fox's new found stardom. The film would go on to be a surprise hit.", u"Michael J. Fox's double was Jeff Glosser, who was a college basketball player at the time.", u'The picture was released during an early-mid 1980s cycle of werewolf movies. These included Wolfen (1981), The Howling (1981), this movie, Howling II: ... Your Sister Is a Werewolf (1985), Full Moon High (1981), Teen Wolf Too (1987), The Company of Wolves (1984), The Marsupials: The Howling III (1987), Silver Bullet (1985), and An American Werewolf in London (1981).', u'Jeph Loeb was hired to write it, because the studio, after the surprising success of Valley Girl (1983), wanted to make a comedy that would cost almost nothing (the production costs amounted to about one million dollars) and take very little time to film.', u'Lynda Wiesmeier (Rhonda) was Playboy\'s "Playmate of the Month" in July 1982.', u"Jay Tarses (Beavers' coach) was a writer, but he'd done some television acting, including Family Ties (1982) with Michael J. Fox.", u"Jerry Levine said that decades later, he's still known all over the world for playing Stiles. One time, a fan of the film recognized him at the Western Wall in Jerusalem.", u"The project came together when Michael J. Fox accepted the lead role and his Family Ties (1982) co-star Meredith Baxter became pregnant, which created a delay in the show's filming, that allowed Fox time to complete filming, and then return to his television show.", u'Rod Daniel admitted the glowing eyes were "cheesy", but said it was "part of the charm."', u'According to Rod Daniel: "I didn\'t say ten words to Michael J. Fox about his character or what we were doing. We were always making the same movie."', u"Michael J. Fox and Jeff Glosser couldn't eat solid food while in make-up. They had milkshakes and soup.", u"The extras were so excited to be a part of the movie, that Rod Daniel said he didn't even have to direct them. They showed up for all six days it took to film the basketball scenes.", u"The studio wanted Scott to dress more like Sean Penn's Jeff Spicoli from Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982). A studio executive even visited the set one day with clothing for Michael J. Fox. He told the executive he was happy with the wardrobe he already had, and that put an end to it.", u'After he filmed the movie, Mark Arnold (Mick) spent several months on the soap opera Santa Barbara (1984). Arnold asked to be killed off the soap by the time the film came out, so he could be free to promote it.', u'James Hampton (Mr. Howard) and James MacKrell (Mr. Thorn) are good friends in real-life.', u'Stiles (Jerry Levine) wears numerous colorful shirts in this movie. They appear in the following order: 1) Yellow shirt that says "Life sucks then you die", 2) Blue "Obnoxious: the movie", 3) Black "What are you looking at Dicknose", 4) Gray "Drunken State Florida", 5) Pink - no text, 6) Gray - unreadable, 7) Black - unreadable, 8) Hawaiian shirt, 9) White - "Wolf Buddy" and 10) a white Teen Wolf shirt. Of all the shirts he wears, only one appears to have no text on it.', u"The beaver mascot logo used in the film was the Oregon State University Beavers' logo, in use by the university at that time.", u'Susan Ursitti (Lisa "Boof" Marconi) had only made one movie before this, Zapped! (1982). Co-Screenwriters Jeph Loeb and Matthew Weisman saw her in that film and knew they wanted her for this role.', u'James Hampton (Mr. Howard) asked Rod Daniel for help defining his character. Daniel told him, "He\'s a guy who knows how to make a casserole."', u"In the script, Scott appears on The Tonight Show (1962). It was the only scene that wasn't shot.", u'James MacKrell (Mr. Thorn) was in another 1980s werewolf movie, The Howling (1981). He was reporter Lew Landers, a role he played again in Gremlins (1984).', u"It was really Jerry Levine on top of the van, not a stuntman. Levine was secured with a wire that ran through the van's roof, up his pants, and around his waist.", u'This was the third film that the late Composer Miles Goodman would score for a film starring Michael J. Fox. The others were High School U.S.A. (1983) and Poison Ivy (1985).', u"All the basketball moves were planned. Michael J. Fox asked if they could try playing unscripted. Rod Daniel briefly let them come up with their own moves, but it didn't go very well.", u'Writers Jeph Loeb and Matthew Wiseman would go onto write the hit film, Commando (1985), which would come out two months later and would set a record for the fastest filming and post-production schedule from start to finish, as filming started in April 1985, and ended in June, and all post-production would take place between July and early September (while this film was in theaters) with the film finally being released in October by 20th Century Fox.', u'The "wolf transition" shots were filmed last.', u'The high school was so close to the airport, they had to stop shooting when planes flew overhead.', u'Harold Howard tells Scott, "With great power comes an even greater responsibility," which is what Uncle Ben tells Peter Parker in the origin story for Spider-Man. Screenwriter Jeph Loeb was also a comic book writer, who wrote Spider-Man comics.', u'The dancing was choreographed by Janet Roston, who later directed the Los Angeles Rock Opera Co. Michael J. Fox had a dance double for some of these scenes. Rod Daniel joked that Fox was a terrible dancer.', u'In Spain it was titled "De pelo en pecho" which is an expression used to say that someone is a "hairy chest male".', u'The film has a very similar premise to I Was a Teenage Werewolf (1957).', u'Rod Daniel was one of the co-writers, producers and directors of the hit television series, WKRP in Cincinnati (1978) which ran from 1978 to 1982. The same year, Family Ties (1982) began to air in the Fall of 82 and starred Michael J. Fox, whom he would direct in this film.', u'There is a clip from Teen Wolf featured in the documentary The Celluoid Closet. It is featured during a montage of people using offensive homosexual terms.', u'Bill Simmons (the famed Sports Guy on ESPN who went on to run Grantland and The Ringer, as well as do multiple projects for ESPN and later HBO) loved the movie, and often used it as a comparison point for NBA players, in calling it a "thinking man\'s basketball film". In his best-selling non-fiction tome "The Book of Basketball", Simmons compared Kobe Bryant\'s career with that of Michael J. Fox\'s title character, noting at length that Kobe had alternated between being a team player and a selfish me-first scorer, not unlike Teen Wolf after he became "the big wolf on campus". Simmons did noted in "The Book of Basketball", that the editing of the basketball scenes in the film was the worst he\'d ever seen for a sports film.', u'Scott Paulin (Mr. Lolley) based his character on his father-in-law, who was an acting teacher.', u'Jerry Levine said the scene with all the shaving cream on the floor made it feel like he was ice skating.', u'In 2008, NFL player Greg White legally changed his name to Stylez White, after Stiles from the movie.', u'There is an MTV show called Teen Wolf (2011). Other than the title, it has little to do with this film.', u"Pamela, Mick, and Mr. Thorne are the film's main antagonists.", u'In the film, it is revealed that Mick (Mark Arnold) had done time in prison, but the crime he committed that landed in prison was not revealed. In the bowling alley scene, Mick says to Scott (Michael J. Fox) "I\'ve handled your kind before. Your mama use to steal chickens out of the backyard until I blew her head off with a shotgun." It\'s likely Mick said that to provoke and insult Scott. If Mick had indeed committed murder, according to American law, Mick would had been given the death penalty or life without the possibility parole or a lesser sentence.', u'When Scott sinks the final shot and wins the game at the end of the movie, he goes into the stands and hugs his father. Immediately behind Michael J. Fox and James Hampton, an extra (in a red sweater) can be seen with an unzipped fly. This incident later resulted in an Internet rumor that the extra is a man exposing himself. However, the unmatted full frame version of the film reveals that the extra is actually a young woman. Apparently her pants were too tight, so she unbuttoned and unzipped them so she could sit down on the bleachers. Filming commenced, when she stood up later (while the final scene was being filmed) she buttoned and zipped up her pants.', u'Originally, Scott was going to start the basketball game as the werewolf, but Rod Daniel decided to have Scott play the whole game as himself.', u'When the crowd is shown after the game winning shot, Emilio Estevez can be seen in front of Boof.', u'In the narrative behind the scene which Pamela removes her bra and seduces Scott. Pamela seduced Scott so she could use him to make Mick jealous, which later causes Mick to lose his cool and assault Scott at the high school dance.', u"In the high school dance sequence, Mick assaults Scott and doesn't get arrested. Mick would had been arrested for assault and could had done three years to sixteen years according to American law. Mick had previously done time in prison for an undisclosed offense."]
